testCases.explanation: Good nodes: root 3 (path max=3, 3>=3), node 4 (max=3, 4>=3), node 3 under 1 (path 3→1→3, max=3, 3>=3), node 5 (path 3→4→5, max=4, 5>=4). Nodes 1 (1<3) and 1 under 4 (1<4) are not good. Total=4.
Good nodes: root 3, left child 3 (path 3→3, 3>=3), left-left child 4 (path 3→3→4, 4>=3). Node 2 (path 3→3→2, 2<3) is not good. Total=3.
Single node; root is always a good node. Total=1.
Tree: root=2(right only)→4→children: 10 (left) and 8 (right). Good: 2 (root), 4 (4>=2), 10 (path 2→4→10, max=4, 10>=4), 8 (path 2→4→8, max=4, 8>=4). Total=4.

All children have values >= max on their root-to-node path (all values are positive and children are >= parent in this tree). Root=1(good), 2(>=1), 3(>=1), 4(path 1→2→4, max=2, 4>=2), 5(5>=2), 6(path 1→3→6, max=3, 6>=3), 7(7>=3). All 7 nodes are good.

description: Given a binary tree root, a node X in the tree is named good if in the path from root to X there are no nodes with a value greater than X's value. Return the number of good nodes in the binary tree.

examples.explanation: Root node(3) is always good. Node 4 (3,4) is the maximum value in its path. Node 3 (3,1,3) equals the path max. Node 5 (3,4,5) is the maximum. Nodes with value 1 are not good because a greater node exists on their path.
Node 2 (path 3,3,2) is not good because 3 is greater than 2.

constraints: The number of nodes in the binary tree is in the range [1, 10^5]
